message_1: A sample of radioactive element X has a half-life of 10 minutes. If the initial amount of X is 200 grams, how much will be left after 30 minutes?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the formula for radioactive decay:

Final amount = Initial amount * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial amount of element X is 200 grams, the half-life is 10 minutes, and the time elapsed is 30 minutes. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final amount = 200 * (1/2)^(30 / 10)

Final amount = 200 * (1/2)^3

Final amount = 200 * (1/8)

Final amount = 25 grams

So, after 30 minutes, there will be 25 grams of element X left.
